--- title: "Rising Wooders: Part 3" subtitle: "Part 3: The role of r-dissimilation" author: "Josef Fruehwald" date: 2023-01-04 categories: - "research" - "linguistics" image: "assets/wooder_path.png" twitter-card: image: "assets/wooder_path.png" card-style: summary_large_image creator: "@jofrhwld" open-graph: image: "assets/wooder_path.png" knitr: opts_chunk: message: false fig-cap-location: bottom bibliography: references.bib order: 02 --- This is part 3 of my blog posts to accompany my ADS2023 Poster. [![](/posts/2022/12/2022-12-31_wooder1/assets/ADS2023-wooder.png){fig-alt="The full American Dialect Society poster for \"Philadelphians' say Wooder, and that's that\"?"}](/posts/2022/12/2022-12-31_wooder1/assets/ADS2023-wooder.png) ## Waughter? Worder? Wooder? In my [first post](../../../2022/12/2022-12-31_wooder1/index.qmd), I talked about the timeline of when Philadelphians came to realize there was something distinctive about the way we say *water*, and the use of \ in print. In my second post, I modelled the timeline of *when* Philadelphians started saying \[w ä…æ…ö\], which seems to have been in variation with \[w…î…æ…ö\] and \[w…î…π…æ…ö\] for people born across the 20^th^ century. Now there's just the question of why any of this happened at all. ## Story 1: \[w…î…æ…ö\] raising One possibility is that changes in the pronunciation of /…î/ just naturally shifted the vowel's pronunciation in *water* in particular. If you look at the \<…î\> symbol on an IPA chart, you'd probably describe it as a mid to low back vowel. However, /…î/ is pretty significantly raised in Philly so that for many speakers its more like a high back vowel. ::: {#fig-oh layout-nrow="1"} !["canonical" …î placement](assets/oh_1.png){#fig-oh1 fig-alt="An illustration of a triangular vowel space with …î placed mid-low and back." fig-align="center" width="25%"} ![Philly …î placement](assets/oh_2.png){#fig-oh2 fig-alt="An illustration of a triangular vowel space with …î placed high and back." fig-align="center" width="25%"} The "canonical" placement of /…î/ vs a typical Philadelphia /…î/ ::: In fact, this is essentially the story we told in 100 Years of Sound Change. ("/oh/" and "open-o" are how we referred to this vowel). > The parallel back vowel is /oh/ in long open-o words talk, lost, off, and so on. Here the social stereotype is firmly fixed on one word, water, pronounced with a high back nucleus. > > @100Years In a lot of ways this story makes sense, since not only is /…î/ very high in Philadelphia, but with it coming immediately after a /w/, the coarticulatory effect could pull it even higher to \[ ä\]. ### Some shortcomings A shortcoming for me about this story is that there are other words with a /w…î/ sequence that *haven't* shifted to \[w ä\]. For example, *wall* \[w…î…´\] is very distinct from *wool* \[w ä…´\] for me. Similarly, none of *walk*, *Waldo*, *walnut*, *Walter*, *waltz* have \[ ä\] in them. This is a classic kind of problem/debate in the study of sound change. Is it exceptionless? Does it happen all at once, or does it move word by word?[^1] This *could* be an example of "lexical diffusion", where for some reason or another, change from \[…î\] ‚û°Ô∏è \[ ä\] happened in just one word, *water*, and not in any of the other words that are similar. [^1]: @labov1981, @Bybee2002, @Phillips2006, @fruehwald2007, and many many others ## Story 2: Passing through Worder. Another possibility here that recently occurred to me is that maybe the \[w…î…π…æ…ö\] tokens I found in the PNC aren't just some third variant in the mix, but are actually evidence of how *water* moved from \[…î\] to \[ ä\]. But it has a few steps to it. ### r-dissimilation Unlike a lot of eastern seaboard cities in North America, like Boston, New York City and Charleston, Philadelphia has always been an /r/ pronouncing city. Where in Boston and NYC they might drop the /r/ in *park* \[p^h^aÀêk\] and *car* \[k^h^aÀê\], Philly has always pronounced that /r/: \[p^h^…í…πk\] and \[k^h^…í…π\].[^2] [^2]: I'll come back to that different vowel in a sec. The one exception to this rule is when there is *more than one /r/* in the word, and if one of those /r/s is dropable, people are likely to drop it [@ellis2006]. This tendency is maybe most notable in the name of a nearby suburb and college "Swarthmore", which is usually pronounced \[sw…ëŒ∏.m…î…π\]. In fact, Swarthmore College recently capitalized on this variation in dueling billboards.[^3] [^3]:

Have you seen the new signs at the @SEPTA train station? üëÄ pic.twitter.com/3DYfiGcRPs

--- Swarthmore College (@swarthmore) August 26, 2022
```{=html} ``` ::: {#fig-swat layout-nrow="1"} !["Swathmore" with the first \ dropped.](assets/swathmore.jpeg){#swat fig-alt="A social media post that reads \"There's only one \"R\" in Swaaathmore - And don't let anyone tell you different.\"" fig-align="center"} !["Swathmore", with the first \ present.](assets/swarthmore.jpeg){#swart fig-alt="A social media image that reads \"There are two R's in Swarthmore. - And don't let anyone tell you different.\"" fig-align="center"} Dueling enregisterments. ::: But, this /r/ dissimilation isn't restricted to just the word "Swarthmore." The first /r/ is usually dropped in words like "quarter" or "corner". ### Reinterpretation I think this /r/ dissimilation is what got "worder" in the door, which I'll try to illustrate with an example. Let's say you're in Philadelphia and from Philadelphia, and some shows you this coin and says "Here's a \[k ∞w…î.…æ…ö\]." ![A quarter](assets/coin.png){#fig-coin fig-alt="The face side of a quarter." fig-align="center" width="25%"} There are two possible ways you could decide to interpret the underlying form of this word. The first would be to take into account /r/ dissimulation, and stick the /r/ back in, for a /k ∞w…î…π.t…πÃ©/ representation. The other would be to *not* take into account /r/ dissimilation, and decided on a /k ∞w…î.t…πÃ©/representation. ![The possible re-interpretations of k ∞w…î.…æ…ö](assets/quarter.png){#fig-quarter fig-alt="A diagram showing how k ∞w…î.…æ…ö could be interpreted as being underlyingly k ∞w…î…π.t…πÃ© or k ∞w…î.t…πÃ©" fig-align="center" width="75%"} Now, let's just take off the \[k ∞\] at the beginning, and we have a remarkably similar kind of interpretation pathways for *water*! ![Possible re-interpretations of w…î.…æ…ö](assets/water_interp.png){#fig-water-interp fig-alt="A diagram showing w…î.…æ…ö being reinterpreted as w…î…π.t…πÃ© or as w…î.t…πÃ©" fig-align="center" width="75%"} ### Merger So, not only is the /w…î…π.t…πÃ©/ reinterpretation plausible, [I *heard* a lot of \[w…î…π…æ…ö\]](../../../2023/01/2023-01-01_wooder2/index.qmd#worder) when I was coding the data. The next thing to know about these vowels in Philly is that the vowels /…î…π/ (as in *tore*) and /u…π/ *tour* have merged to a high back position. Perhaps the most noticeable aspect of this merger is that it's dragged /a…π/, as in *tar*, to a much higher and rounded position in Philly than many other varieties. ::: {#fig-merger layout-ncol="2"} ![*tar*, *tore* and *tour* prior to the merger](assets/pre-merger.png){fig-alt="A vowel space showing *tar* in a low back position, *tore* in a mid back position, and *tour* in a high back position." fig-align="center" width="37%"} ![*tar*, *tore* and *tour* after the merger](assets/post-merger.png){fig-alt="A vowel space showing *tar* in a mid back position, and both tore and tour in a high back position." fig-align="center"} Before and after the merger ::: If people were inserting an /…π/ into the middle of *water*, it would belong to this /…î…π/ vowel, and we would expect it to be merged into /u…π/. So, once you've put an /…π/ into the middle of *water* and merged it with /u…π/, what do you get if you then do /r/ dissimilation on *that*? ### Wooder! ![My proposed pathway of "wooder" development.](assets/wooder_path.png){#fig-wooder-path fig-align="center"} ### Shortcomings So, a shortcoming of this story about how we got "wooder" is that it could seem a little convoluted. Like we decided to just stick an /…π/ in just to delete it later, and voil√†! Wooder! ### Benefits On the other hand, there *are* a bunch of \[w…î…π…æ…ö\] tokens in the Philadelphia Neighborhood Corpus. It also would account for why non of the other /w…î/ words had this shift to \[ ä\]. It *also* captures a but of what's going on with *daughter* [as satirized by the SNL skit Murder Durder](../../../2023/01/2023-01-01_wooder2/index.qmd#the-coding-scheme). ## Which story is the right one? I'd say I need to do a bit more work, looking at the acoustic data more closely, looking at how individuals vary, as well as looking at *daughter* and the other /…î…π/ words that both have and don't have /r/ dissimilation to really get closer to settling the issue. But I think the way you react to each account could shed a little light on the kind of linguistic analyses you prefer. I really like Story 2. All the pieces that make it work are happening and have been described *already*, so I didn't need to describe any new phenomenon to get "water" to turn into "wooder". It just got pulled up in the interplay of different sound changes. It looks like a beautiful pattern, to me. However, maybe Story 2 looks overwrought to you. "Words just do things sometimes!" you might say. "The /…î/ was rising, and there's a /w/ *right there*!" And you know what, fair enough! That was my own analysis until about a year ago as well. The good news is that Story 2 has piqued my interest, which means I'm going to be digging into this more in the near future. And maybe as I go I'll find the "passage through worder" account unsupported, but for right now it seems really plausible to me!
